body_html:
And just to make things more concrete, here are images showing the different behaviors on the same wavenet training loss data.

The previous behavior with the "noisy" end section was like this:

The behavior currently in master (or what you would get in master if tf-tensorboard.html were updated) is this:

It does remove the noisy bit at the end, but leaves one unable to see the most recent trend.

And the behavior with the change in this PR preserves the smoothed line all the way to the end:
body_text:
And just to make things more concrete, here are images showing the different behaviors on the same wavenet training loss data.
The previous behavior with the "noisy" end section was like this:

The behavior currently in master (or what you would get in master if tf-tensorboard.html were updated) is this:

It does remove the noisy bit at the end, but leaves one unable to see the most recent trend.
And the behavior with the change in this PR preserves the smoothed line all the way to the end:
body:
And just to make things more concrete, here are images showing the different behaviors on the same wavenet training loss data.

The previous behavior with the "noisy" end section was like this:
![p_old](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2138320/23343680/48d9d818-fc35-11e6-9860-cb1bc90cc9e5.png)

The behavior currently in master (or what you would get in master if tf-tensorboard.html were updated) is this:
![p_prev](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2138320/23343695/5f9a3552-fc35-11e6-929d-d47c7a954954.png)

It does remove the noisy bit at the end, but leaves one unable to see the most recent trend.

And the behavior with the change in this PR preserves the smoothed line all the way to the end:
![p_thispr](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2138320/23343701/7aacde80-fc35-11e6-9ddd-57a4da7233e3.png)
